topics: Introduction to Optimization Winter 2025
walaa.moursi@uwaterloo.ca
Instructor: Walaa Moursi walaa.moursi@uwaterloo.ca
A broad introduction to the field of optimization, discussing applications, and solution techniques.
Mathematical models for real life applications; algorithms; aspects of computational complexity; geometry; linear programming duality, focusing on the development of algorithms.
Carry out the computations by hand for simple instances of various algorithms such as the Simplex.
Formulate the dual of various linear programs.
Reproduce the main proofs in the course and prove simple related concepts independently.
The simplest models are linear programs where both the constraints and the objective functions are linear.
Even though this may appear at a first glance to be overly restrictive, linear programming algorithms are used widely across most branches of industry.
In these cases, we would like to add the condition that some variables in our linear program take integer values only.
These models are known as integer programs.

Finally, in certain instances, such as portfolio optimization (in financial mathematics), the natural way of formulating the optimization problem may require the use of non-linear constraints, or a non-linear objective function.
In the first part of this course, we will illustrate these various models with examples that arise from real problems.
The Simplex algorithm to solve linear programs will be discussed in some detail and general-purpose integer programming techniques such as branch-and-bound and cutting planes will also be described.
These algorithms while guaranteed to terminate, may in the worst case (and often do in practice) take a prohibitively long time.
An indispensable tool for the design of such fast algorithms is the theory of duality, which will be a main focus of this course.
We will move towards the conclusion of the course with a review of the various techniques used to solve linear and integer programs and by providing a geometric interpretation of these algorithms.
This discussion will lead us to non-linear convex optimization problems.
Also included in this last part of the material are approximation algorithms.
Shows a linear programming polytope together with a possible path (red) taken by the simplex method to solve the corresponding LP.

Students will gain an understanding of how organizations identify the needs of potential consumers and create and deliver value to these consumers through the marketing process.

Certain concepts from business and economics including market responsiveness, decision-making process, willingness to purchase, product differentiation, and advertising will be incorporated into the development of a strategic marketing plan.

In addition to teaching central concepts and models from both marketing and economic theory, students will be placed in a forum where they can apply these concepts in a 'real world' marketing situation.
Describe the basic principles of marketing, the marketing process, and its economic foundation.
Demonstrate how marketing discovers and satisfies consumer needs and wants.
Analyze internal and external factors contributing to the current state of organizations.
Demonstrate the use of marketing tools including branding, positioning, and segmentation.
Integrate the marketing mix elements into a strategic marketing plan.

Introduction to Optimization Winter 2025
walaa.moursi@uwaterloo.ca
Instructor: Walaa Moursi walaa.moursi@uwaterloo.ca
A broad introduction to the field of optimization, discussing applications, and solution techniques.
Mathematical models for real life applications; algorithms; aspects of computational complexity; geometry; linear programming duality, focusing on the development of algorithms.
Carry out the computations by hand for simple instances of various algorithms such as the Simplex.
Formulate the dual of various linear programs.
Reproduce the main proofs in the course and prove simple related concepts independently.
The simplest models are linear programs where both the constraints and the objective functions are linear.
Even though this may appear at a first glance to be overly restrictive, linear programming algorithms are used widely across most branches of industry.
In these cases, we would like to add the condition that some variables in our linear program take integer values only.
These models are known as integer programs.

Finally, in certain instances, such as portfolio optimization (in financial mathematics), the natural way of formulating the optimization problem may require the use of non-linear constraints, or a non-linear objective function.
In the first part of this course, we will illustrate these various models with examples that arise from real problems.
The Simplex algorithm to solve linear programs will be discussed in some detail and general-purpose integer programming techniques such as branch-and-bound and cutting planes will also be described.
These algorithms while guaranteed to terminate, may in the worst case (and often do in practice) take a prohibitively long time.
An indispensable tool for the design of such fast algorithms is the theory of duality, which will be a main focus of this course.
We will move towards the conclusion of the course with a review of the various techniques used to solve linear and integer programs and by providing a geometric interpretation of these algorithms.
This discussion will lead us to non-linear convex optimization problems.
Also included in this last part of the material are approximation algorithms.

Introduction to Differential Equations Winter 2025
Solving linear differential equations: first- and second-order scalar equations and first-order vector equations.
The main purpose of the course is to explore how first and second order differential equations (DEs) are used to model physical systems and predict their behaviour.
first order linear DE models of compartment problems, atomic decay, and bodies in motion;
first order separable DE models of population growth;
a first order exact DE model of the electric dipole;
second order linear DE models for oscillatory systems such as mass-spring-damper systems and electrical circuits;
second order nonlinear DE models for suspended cables and rocket motion;
linear vector DE models of multiple compartment problems and species interactions.
Both analytical solution techniques and qualitative methods (direction field analysis, dimensional analysis, and phase portraits) will be presented as ways to gain information about system behaviour.
We will investigate conditions for existence, uniqueness, and continuity of solutions of both first and second order initial value problems, and for systems in the plane.
Maple will be used to generate numerical and graphical solutions, to illustrate concepts graphically, and to explore model behaviour.
increase your comprehension of some of the many ways that differential equations can help us understand the real world;
develop your ability to understand a mathematical model for a specific situation;
explore analytical and qualitative solution methods for first and second order differential equations, and the use of Maple; and

course_name: AMATH343 - Discrete Models in Applied Mathematics (0.50)
topics: Discrete Models in Applied Mathematics Fall 2023
Difference equations and discrete dynamical systems.
Mathematical models are taken from ecology, biology, economics, and other fields.

Many such systems evolve over continuous time and can be modelled by differential equations, however, there are some systems for which the evolution is more appropriately described using discrete time intervals - for example, plant and animal populations where breeding and other effects can be assumed to take place at particular times of the year.
As with differential equations, difference equations can be classified as linear difference equations and nonlinear difference equations.
First, we will examine linear difference equations and a number of standard methods to solve them.
The asymptotic behaviour of nonlinear systems can be quite complicated, leading to such things as “bifurcations,” “chaos,” and “fractals.”
A few simple models will be studied in order to understand certain aspects of this behaviour.
We will explore the notion of “fractal dimension” as well as some simple methods of generating fractal sets.
Time permitting, we will look at iterated function systems (IFS), a simple, yet powerful, geometric method of generating and studying fractal sets.

Complex Analysis Winter 2025
Complex numbers provide the natural setting in which to study differentiable functions.

Cauchy's theorem plays a central role in this subject, and many important results follow from it: Cauchy's integral formula, the theory of Taylor and Laurent series, Cauchy's residue theorem, the argument principle, the fundamental theorem of algebra, the maximum modulus theorem, Mittag-Lefler expansions, and Weierstrass products.

We’ll start the course with a basic review of complex numbers, and the complex exponential and logarithm, complex analytic functions, and make our way towards Cauchy's theorem and its wonderful consequences.
My lectures will draw on a number of books and sources, but I recommend Knopp's Elements of the Theory of Functions, and his Theory of Functions Parts I and II.
Another reference is Marsden and Hoffman's Basic Complex Analysis.

Introduction to Optimization Winter 2025
walaa.moursi@uwaterloo.ca
Instructor: Walaa Moursi walaa.moursi@uwaterloo.ca
A broad introduction to the field of optimization, discussing applications, and solution techniques.
Mathematical models for real life applications; algorithms; aspects of computational complexity; geometry; linear programming duality, focusing on the development of algorithms.
Carry out the computations by hand for simple instances of various algorithms such as the Simplex.
Formulate the dual of various linear programs.
Reproduce the main proofs in the course and prove simple related concepts independently.
The simplest models are linear programs where both the constraints and the objective functions are linear.
Even though this may appear at a first glance to be overly restrictive, linear programming algorithms are used widely across most branches of industry.
In these cases, we would like to add the condition that some variables in our linear program take integer values only.
These models are known as integer programs.

Finally, in certain instances, such as portfolio optimization (in financial mathematics), the natural way of formulating the optimization problem may require the use of non-linear constraints, or a non-linear objective function.
In the first part of this course, we will illustrate these various models with examples that arise from real problems.
The Simplex algorithm to solve linear programs will be discussed in some detail and general-purpose integer programming techniques such as branch-and-bound and cutting planes will also be described.
These algorithms while guaranteed to terminate, may in the worst case (and often do in practice) take a prohibitively long time.
An indispensable tool for the design of such fast algorithms is the theory of duality, which will be a main focus of this course.
We will move towards the conclusion of the course with a review of the various techniques used to solve linear and integer programs and by providing a geometric interpretation of these algorithms.
This discussion will lead us to non-linear convex optimization problems.
Also included in this last part of the material are approximation algorithms.

Mohammad Abuyaghi
Email: mohammad.abuyaghi@uwaterloo.ca
An introduction to networks, protocols, and distributed systems.
Exemplify the basic functionality and components of an operating system.
Recall, explain, and compare transmission media and access control schemes.
Recall, summarize, and exemplify connection management and reliable message transmission.
Recall, explain, and compare naming and name resolution techniques, including mobility.
Recall, summarize, and explain security/privacy concepts in network protocols and distributed systems
Recall, explain, and compare high-level communication services and distribution services.

We will take a ‘top-down’ approach to networking and distributed systems, focusing on the networking concepts and distributed systems mechanisms underlying widely used networked applications and systems.
Application layer
Network layer
Routing principles: Link state and distance vector algorithms, hierarchical routing, routing among autonomous systems.
Security
Distributed systems
Design principles: End-to-end principle, hierarchy, replication and failover, etc.
A Top-Down Approach, James Kurose & Keith Ross, Pearson No
Distributed Systems: Principles and Paradigms, Maarten Van Steen & Andrew S. Tanenbaum, Prentice Hall No

course_name: PMATH334 - Introduction to Rings and Fields with Applications (0.50)
topics: This course provides an introduction to the fundamental algebraic structures of rings and fields, with an emphasis on their properties and applications.
Topics include polynomial rings, field extensions, and their connections to areas such as number theory and geometry.
Memerize fundamental concepts of algebraic structures, including groups, rings, integral domains, fields, vector space, etc.
Analyze structures of rings and fields using homomorphisms.
Analyze and identify reducibility of a polynomial over a field
Understand field extension and be able to construct extension fields
Understand some standard algebra proof techniques.

Week 9 Unique Factorization Domains, Divisibility in Polynomial Rings Chapter 6, 7
Week 12 Extension Fields Chapter 9
Week 13 Straight-edge and Compasses Constructions  Chapter 10

A general survey course designed to provide the student with an understanding of the basic concepts and techniques of modern psychology as a behavioural science.
Introductory Psychology will introduce students to the fundamental theories, concepts, methods, and issues encountered in the field of psychology.

In addition to learning the core concepts of the field, this course is also meant to instruct the student in the scientific method (as it is used in the social sciences), to give students insight into themselves and their relationships with others, and to develop skills that will help students be successful in university and beyond.
Explain and apply the core concepts of psychology.
This will provide a foundation of knowledge upon which you can build in upper year psychology courses.
Gain greater insight into yourself, others, and the human condition: Apply core concepts to yourself and others; recognize and value human diversity.

A general survey course designed to provide the student with an understanding of the basic concepts and techniques of modern psychology as a behavioural science.
We will explore topics ranging from human development throughout the lifespan, to learning and memory, to psychological disorders and the therapies that are used to treat them.
Explain key concepts from across the discipline of psychology using appropriate terminology.
Describe the methods of investigation used in psychology, and the strengths and limitations of these methods.
Identify and communicate the influence of psychological concepts on behaviour and/or systems in everyday situations.
Apply the findings of psychological research to your life and to important issues in our society and the world at large.
